dt: {bc}to divide lengthwise usually along a grain or seam or by layers
{bc}to affect as if by cleaving or forcing apart

dt.t: the river {wi}splits{/wi} the town in two

dt: {bc}to subject (an atom or atomic nucleus) to artificial disintegration by fission
{bc}to affect as if by breaking up or tearing apart {bc}{sx|shatter||}
{bc}to divide into parts or portions: such as
{bc}to divide into factions, parties, or groups
{bc}to mark (a ballot) or cast or register (a vote) so as to vote for candidates of different parties
{bc}to divide or break down (a chemical compound) into constituents

dt.t: {wi}split{/wi} a fat into glycerol and fatty acids

dt: {bc}to divide (stock) by issuing a larger number of shares to existing shareholders usually without increase in total par value
{bc}to separate (the parts of a whole) by interposing something
{bc}to become split lengthwise or into layers
{bc}to become divided up or separated off

pt: {sc}tear{/sc} {sc}rip{/sc} {sc}rend{/sc} {sc}split{/sc} {sc}cleave{/sc} {sc}rive{/sc} mean to separate forcibly. {sc}tear{/sc} implies pulling apart by force and leaving jagged edges.
{sc}rip{/sc} implies a pulling apart in one rapid uninterrupted motion often along a line or joint.
{sc}rend{/sc} implies very violent or ruthless severing or sundering.

pt.t: an angry mob {it}rent{/it} the prisoner's clothes

pt: {sc}split{/sc} implies a cutting or breaking apart in a continuous, straight, and usually lengthwise direction or in the direction of grain or layers.
{sc}cleave{/sc} implies very forceful splitting or cutting with a blow.

pt.t: a bolt of lightning {it}cleaved{/it} the giant oak

pt: {sc}rive{/sc} occurs most often in figurative use.

et: Dutch {it}splitten{/it}, from Middle Dutch; akin to Middle High German {it}splīzen{/it} to split and probably to Old High German {it}spaltan{/it} to split
shortdef: to divide lengthwise usually along a grain or seam or by layers
to affect as if by cleaving or forcing apart
to tear or rend apart : burst

dt: used especially by breeders of cage birds sometimes with {it}for{/it}

shortdef: heterozygous —used especially by breeders of cage birds sometimes with for

dt: {bc}a narrow break made by or as if by {a_link|splitting}
{bc}an arrangement of bowling pins left standing with space for pins between them
{bc}a piece split off or made thin by splitting
{bc}a division into or between divergent or antagonistic elements or forces
{bc}the act or process of splitting something (such as the stock of a corporation)
{bc}the act of lowering oneself to the floor or leaping into the air with legs extended at right angles to the trunk
{bc}a product of division by or as if by splitting
{bc}a wine bottle holding one quarter the usual amount or about .1875 liters (6 to 6.5 ounces)
{bc}an ice cream sundae served over slices of fruit (such as banana)
{bc}the recorded time at or for a specific part of a race

shortdef: a narrow break made by or as if by splitting
an arrangement of bowling pins left standing with space for pins between them
a piece split off or made thin by splitting

shortdef: city and port on the Dalmatian coast of the Adriatic Sea in southern Croatia population 166,500

dt: {bc}having the optic chiasma and corpus callosum severed

shortdef: having the optic chiasma and corpus callosum severed

dt: {bc}a decision in a boxing match reflecting a division of opinion among the referee and judges

shortdef: a decision in a boxing match reflecting a division of opinion among the referee and judges

dt: {bc}an offensive football end who lines up usually several yards to the side of the formation
{bc}a hair tip that has become frayed (as from dryness)

shortdef: a fastball thrown with the ball gripped as for a forkball so that it drops rapidly as it nears the plate —called also split-finger, splitter

dt: {bc}an infinitive with {it}to{/it} having a modifier between the {it}to{/it} and the verbal (as in "to really start")

pt: The split infinitive was discovered and named in the 19th century. 19th century writers seem to have made greater use of this construction than earlier writers; the frequency of occurrence attracted the disapproving attention of grammarians, many of whom thought it to be a modern corruption. The construction had in fact been in occasional use since the 14th century; only its frequency had changed. Even though there has never been a rational basis for objecting to the split infinitive, the subject has become a fixture of folk belief about grammar. You can hardly publish a sentence containing one without hearing about it from somebody. Modern commentators know the split infinitive is not a vice, but they are loath to drop such a popular subject. They usually say it's all right to split an infinitive in the interest of clarity. Since clarity is the usual reason for splitting, this advice means merely that you can split them whenever you need to.

shortdef: an infinitive with to having a modifier between the to and the verbal (as in "to really start")

dt: {bc}divided vertically so that the floor level of rooms in one part is approximately midway between the levels of two successive stories in an adjoining part

shortdef: divided vertically so that the floor level of rooms in one part is approximately midway between the levels of two successive stories in an adjoining part
